title: MM-POISONRAG: Disrupting Multimodal RAG with Local and Global Poisoning Attacks
author: Hyeonjeong Ha (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Qiusi Zhan (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Jeonghwan Kim (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Dimitrios Bralios (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Saikrishna Sanniboina (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Nanyun Peng (University of California Los Angeles), Kai-wei Chang (University of California Los Angeles), ..., Heng Ji (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign)
relevance_why: The research explores adversarial attacks on multimodal systems, which could provide insights for improving robustness in audio and speech processing systems used for multimodal generative tasks.
background: The paper investigates vulnerabilities in multimodal retrieval-augmented generation systems by introducing poisoning attacks that disrupt their ability to generate accurate outputs.
contribution: This paper introduces the MM-POISONRAG framework to expose how adversarial knowledge can poison retrieval processes, achieving significant disruption in model outputs.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods examined knowledge poisoning primarily in text-based models but did not specifically address the risks in multimodal retrieval frameworks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work implements a two-strategy attack (Localized and Globalized Poisoning Attacks) tailored for multimodal contexts, showcasing new vulnerabilities unique to these systems.

key_innovation: The dual-attack strategy enabling precise manipulation of answers for specific queries as well as widespread disruption across multiple queries distinguishes this framework.
real_world_impact: The findings highlight essential security risks in multimodal RAG systems, necessitating the development of robust defenses against misinformation and biased outputs.
limitations: The study mainly focuses on QA tasks without exploring its applicability across other multimodal settings.
